addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable S
r
Robert Cecill knight one of her Hig
es
privie Counsell.

6 June
1594
M
r
Bodeley to my M
r
From
e Haghe

page.lettertext:
fol.243r
May it please yo
r
H. to be advertised,
at I
receaved yo
r
letter of
e 24 of
e last,
e 2 of this
p
nt
, and a letter thereinclosed from her
Hig
es
to
e
states,
w
ch
I delivered unto them
e next day after,
and they promised to answear, when according to
their custome, they shall have taken some time to de-
liberat upon it. Howe they have agreed to satis-
fie her Ma
tie
for
e pointes of my Instructions, I
have formerly signified unto my
L. Treasurer
,
and sent their owne letter to
e self same effect, ha-
ving no other cause to remaine at
e Hage, but onely
to attend her Hig
es
further pleasure. In
e meane
while I doe not cease to sollicit
e chief of
e Deputies,
both to calle upon
e
Provinces,
to arme as many
shippes, as conveniently they may, and to returne
their answear hither, assoone as is possible. I have
also written to Co Maurice, to
e very same purpose,
and requested
S
r
Francis Vere
, to urge him to it very
earnestly. I am informed at this inst
a
t,
at there are Hoyes sent to
Flushing
for embarking
the companies, for w
ch
I thinke it very requisit, to
calle for those supplies, w
ch
they have promised heere,
and will perfourme, I doe not doubt, assoone as
shall be needefull. Although I knowe
at
M
r
Gilpin
doth keepe his course in reporting all other
occurrences, yet unwilling
at my l
re
should come
emptie to yo
r
H. I can not but advertise, that
heere is very great hope of
e taking of
Groeninghen:
partly by reason they are devided among themselves,
and partly for that they can hardly
be
relieved,
w
t
further succo
rs
from
e Enemie, by meanes of o
r
forces, w
ch
lie upon
e passages. Nevertheles they
fol.243v
doe not shewe any token in
e course of their defense,
that they will give it over hastely. For they shoote
very thicke, and make many salies, and put us often
to
e worse: and in that respect
e Englishe have had
their part aswell as others: besides
at many falle sicke
of
e companies lastly levied. We have cer-
taine intelligence,
at
e D. du Mayne having bin at
Brussels
w
t
Ernestus
for two or three daies is depar-
ted from thens w
t
l
re
s of Exchange for 80000 ducates
and w
t
assurance by promise to be further assisted,
both w
t
horse and foote, w
ch
are gathering in great
numbers w
t
all expedition.
Verdugo,
as we heare,
hath sent already into France 700 horse, in lieu of
w
ch
, it should seeme by l
re
s from
Andwerpe,
Ernestus
is minded to send his Spaniardes into
Friseland,
w
ch
is also thought
e rather, for
at
e Spaniards are not
welcome to
e
Co. Charles Mansfelt
. The Count,
it is written, having left La Chappelle, is come as farre
as
Guise
, and advanceth his armie towardes
e
kinge,
who, we say, at this p
nt
besiegeth
Laon,
and is so farre
engaged, as he can not w
t
his honor but attend
e others
comming: w
ch
hath raised heere w
t
us a great expecta-
tion of
e event of their meeting. In effect this
is all
at of
e speeches heere w
t
us I finde worthe
the writing:
for w
ch
I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. June 6 1594.
Yo
r
H. at commaundem
t
. Tho. Bodley
